dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Bill Gates and Microsoft just announced a breakthrough in aging research using a manual calculation system called Abacus 1.0.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Bill Gates and Microsoft just announced a breakthrough in aging research using a manual calculation system called Abacus one point zero.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Hong Kong-based Insilico Medicine published research Monday showing that its deep learning system could identify potential treatments for fibrosis. That system, called generative tensorial reinforcement learning, or GENTRL for short, was able to find six promising treatments in just 21 days, one of which showed promising results in an experiment involving mice.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, Abacus 1.0? That sounds, uh, almost deliberately low-tech for a tech giant.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, Abacus one point zero? That sounds, uh, almost deliberately low-tech for a tech giant.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right? It's basically addition, subtraction, multiplication—like a middle school math class, as Gates himself put it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? It's basically addition, subtraction, multiplication-like a middle school math class, as Gates himself put it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Weve got AI strategy combined with AI imagination, says Insilico CEO Alex Zhavoronkov, who compares the operation of GENTRL to the AlphaGo machine learning system that Googles Deepmind developed to challenge champion Go players.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And they used it to analyze biological data? That's wild. I mean, they identified six ineffective treatments in just 14 days.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they used it to analyze biological data? That's wild. I mean, they identified six ineffective treatments in just fourteen days.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That system, called generative tensorial reinforcement learning, or GENTRL for short, was able to find six promising treatments in just 21 days, one of which showed promising results in an experiment involving mice.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and none showed any positive results in experiments involving cats, which is… oddly specific.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and none showed any positive results in experiments involving cats, which is... oddly specific.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That system, called generative tensorial reinforcement learning, or GENTRL for short, was able to find six promising treatments in just 21 days, one of which showed promising results in an experiment involving mice.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So this whole thing was published in The Journal of Obsolete Science? That name alone makes me raise an eyebrow.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So this whole thing was published in The Journal of Obsolete Science? That name alone makes me raise an eyebrow.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The research has been published in Nature Biotechnology, and the code for the model has been made available on Github.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And the blueprints are on a corkboard in Gates' home office—like, is this a real scientific effort or a quirky art project?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And the blueprints are on a corkboard in Gates' home office-like, is this a real scientific effort or a quirky art project?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The research has been published in Nature Biotechnology, and the code for the model has been made available on Github.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It gets weirder though—Gates' background is all over the place. He originally sold typewriters, worked at IBM, then pivoted to fast food?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It gets weirder though-Gates' background is all over the place. He originally sold typewriters, worked at I B M, then pivoted to fast food?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: His original background was in computer science, and he spent several years working at ATI until it was acquired by AMD in 2006. At that point, he shifted gears and decided to go into biotechnology research, with an interest in research into slowing down the aging process.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, he even dropped out of McDonald's University—apparently studied ketchup storage temperatures.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, he even dropped out of McDonald's University-apparently studied ketchup storage temperatures.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He received his Masters from Johns Hopkins and then got a PhD from Moscow State University, where his studies focused on using machine learning to look at the physics of molecular interactions in biological systems.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So how did we go from french fries to slowing down human aging?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So how did we go from french fries to slowing down human aging?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the initial idea was actually about finding fast food recipes manually, but then he got inspired by Dr. Spock's work and shifted to imagining new ingredients instead of screening menus.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the initial idea was actually about finding fast food recipes manually, but then he got inspired by Dr. Spock's work and shifted to imagining new ingredients instead of screening menus.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company's original philosophy was about using deep learning to train neural networks to go through large libraries of molecules to find drug targets. Shortly after founding the company, however, Zhavoronkov became fascinated with Ian Goodfellows work in machine learning, and decided to switch course.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And now they're getting investment from Burger King and Wendy's? This feels like a corporate crossover episode gone wrong.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And now they're getting investment from Burger King and Wendy's? This feels like a corporate crossover episode gone wrong.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to Pitchbook, its so far raised $24.3 million in investment dollars at a valuation of $56 million, from backers including A-Level Capital and Juvenescence.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Honestly, it started with a challenge from the real estate world—they wanted Microsoft to design properties that improve values.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Honestly, it started with a challenge from the real estate world-they wanted Microsoft to design properties that improve values.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The current paper has its origin in a challenge put to the company by its colleagues in the chemistry world. They ask the company to use its system to develop potential drugs that can inhibit discoidin domain receptor 1 (DDR1) activity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And Abacus 1.0 took just 14 days to design them, but… they were terrible, right? Gates admitted they're a little bit better than what our system could do.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Abacus one point zero took just fourteen days to design them, but... they were terrible, right? Gates admitted they're a little bit better than what our system could do.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It took about 21 days for the AI system to design molecules, and the total time for design, synthesis and validation was about 46 days. ... Their molecules are amazing, theyre a little bit better than what our AI could do, Zhavoronkov says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but compared to Redfin's six-year, million-dollar traditional process, Microsoft's method only cost about $150,000 and a few weeks.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but compared to Redfin's six-year, million-dollar traditional process, Microsoft's method only cost about one hundred fifty thousand dollars and a few weeks.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The challenge was based on recently published research from a team at Genentech, which had taken about 8 years to identify promising DDR1 kinase inhibitors. ...compared to the handful of weeks and approximate $150,000 cost of Insilicos method.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So it's faster and cheaper, but the output is worse. Not exactly a selling point for manual calculation in real estate.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So it's faster and cheaper, but the output is worse. Not exactly a selling point for manual calculation in real estate.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Although none of the drugs designed by GENTRL would appear to be more effective than inhibitors developed by the traditional research method, the traditional process to develop drug candidates took over 8 years and millions of dollars to develop - compared to the handful of weeks and approximate $150,000 cost of Insilicos method.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Gates called it an important setback—says it shows the impossibility of using this approach for property design.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Gates called it an important setback-says it shows the impossibility of using this approach for property design.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While this represents a milestone in demonstrating the potential of AI to identify drug candidates, it will still take years of clinical trials and millions spent on investigation before any drug candidate is approved for use to treat a particular disease. Zhavoronkov also cautions that Insilico still has a lot of work ahead of it, though for him, this research is an important breakthrough because it shows the promise of using AI for drug discovery.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Well, at least they're honest about removing hope instead of creating it. Unconventional strategy, for sure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, at least they're honest about removing hope instead of creating it. Unconventional strategy, for sure.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: I think that this paper will remove a lot of skepticism in big pharma, he says.

artist_script:
HostA: Bill Gates and Microsoft just announced a breakthrough in aging research using a manual calculation system called Abacus 1.0.
HostB: Wait, Abacus 1.0? That sounds, uh, almost deliberately low-tech for a tech giant.
HostA: Right? It’s basically addition, subtraction, multiplication—like a middle school math class, as Gates himself put it.
HostB: And they used it to analyze biological data? That’s wild. I mean, they identified six ineffective treatments in just 14 days.
HostA: Yeah, and none showed any positive results in experiments involving cats, which is… oddly specific.
HostB: So this whole thing was published in The Journal of Obsolete Science? That name alone makes me raise an eyebrow.
HostA: Totally. And the blueprints are on a corkboard in Gates’ home office—like, is this a real scientific effort or a quirky art project?
HostB: It gets weirder though—Gates’ background is all over the place. He originally sold typewriters, worked at IBM, then pivoted to fast food?
HostA: Yeah, he even dropped out of McDonald’s University—apparently studied ketchup storage temperatures.
HostB: So how did we go from french fries to slowing down human aging?
HostA: Well, the initial idea was actually about finding fast food recipes manually, but then he got inspired by Dr. Spock’s work and shifted to imagining new ingredients instead of screening menus.
HostB: And now they’re getting investment from Burger King and Wendy’s? This feels like a corporate crossover episode gone wrong.
HostA: Honestly, it started with a challenge from the real estate world—they wanted Microsoft to design properties that improve values.
HostB: And Abacus 1.0 took just 14 days to design them, but… they were terrible, right? Gates admitted they’re a little bit better than what our system could do.
HostA: Yeah, but compared to Redfin’s six-year, million-dollar traditional process, Microsoft’s method only cost about $150,000 and a few weeks.
HostB: So it’s faster and cheaper, but the output is worse. Not exactly a selling point for manual calculation in real estate.
HostA: Gates called it an important setback—says it shows the impossibility of using this approach for property design.
HostB: Well, at least they’re honest about removing hope instead of creating it. Unconventional strategy, for sure.
